articles.name: Filtering and Sorting Candidate Test Reports
articles.title: Filtering and Sorting Candidate Test Reports
articles.body:
Overview

You can use a combination of various filters to search and view relevant reports. You can filter reports with filters such as the candidate's name, email id, and status. After you have filtered reports, you can also sort these reports based on your selected criteria.

Prerequisites

  • You must be logged in to your HackerRank for Work account.
  • You must have created a test for which you want to view reports.

Steps

  1. Click the Tests tab on the home page and then click the required test.
  2. Click on the Candidates option from the test page.
  3. Now you have the complete list of the candidates who has been invited or took part in that test.  
  4. On the left pane you have the Candidate Status filters which allows you to filter the precise list of candidates based on your requirement.  

Note: The report list automatically refreshes to display the appropriate data when you enter or select any of the filters.

The available default filters are:

  • Candidate Status: Enables you to filter the candidates by their test status such as passed, failed, In progress, to be evaluated etc…  
  • Total Score: This filter enables you to set a range of score to filter the candidates fallin in that score zone. 
  • Invited By: This filter enables you to filter the candidates invited by you vs the ones who joined using the public url.  
  • Invited On: This filter lets you find the candidates invited between a particular time frame. 
  • Invitation expiry date: This filter enables you to find the candidates whose Invitation expired on a certain date.  
  • You can also add a separate filter by clicking the Add Filter from the filters section.

articles.name: Scoring an HTML/CSS/JavaScript Question
articles.title: Scoring an HTML/CSS/JavaScript Question
articles.body: The test setters manually score HTML/CSS/JavaScript questions. This is because the crucial part of the HTML/CSS/JavaScript question is visual. The test setter must view how the final webpage appears and responds to evaluate the code. You can view the code and render it in the browser for evaluation.

articles.name: Database Engineer Questions
articles.title: Database Engineer Questions
articles.body:
HackerRank for Work provides specially assembled Database Engineering questions that allow you to assess a candidate’s SQL skills. In a test for the Database Engineer role, candidates are tested on their knowledge of Database Management Systems.

Database Management System refers to the technology of storing, modifying, and retrieving data of the users efficiently while taking appropriate security measures. You can test a candidate's knowledge of queries required to retrieve relevant data through a Database Engineering question.

Learn how to create and score a question meant for Database Engineer roles here: 

  1. Creating a Database Engineer Question
  2. Scoring a Database Engineer Question

articles.name: Can I Edit HackerRank Library Questions?
articles.title: Can I Edit HackerRank Library Questions?
articles.body:
You cannot edit or change the associated details of a HackerRank library question. You can only edit the questions in your personal library.
For example, you cannot change the score for a HackerRank library question. The score for the HackerRank library questions is based on the internal scoring system of HackerRank, which takes the difficulty of the question into consideration.

However, you can clone a question from the HackerRank library and change the cloned question according to your requirement. Click here to learn more about how to clone HackerRank Library Questions.

When cloning a question, ensure that you will no longer receive any new updates that are made to the original library question.  

Once a question is cloned, you will be able to edit every detail of that question.

articles.name: Getting Candidates for Your Event
articles.title: Getting Candidates for Your Event
articles.body:
Overview

Once you have set up your event, you can get candidates through these different ways:

  • Publish the Event on Social Channels
  • Import Candidates with a CSV Upload
  • Publish the Event on the HackerRank Community

Publish the Event on Social Channels

Ensure you publish your event on various avenues, such as social channels (Facebook, LinkedIn, Google, and so on) and your own career site. This is to ensure a good number of registrations for the event. Additionally, publishing in our community can also help you get candidates to the event.

Once you publish your microsite on various avenues, candidates will start registering for this event. Based on whether your event is Individual or Team-based, the registration process works as follows:

Registration for an Individual Challenge

For an individual event, a candidate is asked to share their information to register for the event. 

Candidate experience for an individual challenge

 

Registration for a Team-based Event

However, for a team based event, a candidate needs to register as a team leader along with adding their team info. Using the team info, HackerRank Engage sends out an email to all the team members to register for the team that the team leader registers. You can see the difference in the candidate experience for a team leader vs a team member below:

Team-leader registration experience with the team-info

 

Team-member registration experience

Import Candidates with a CSV Upload

Finally, you can also connect your ATS and CRMs through the CSV upload capability to bring in candidates from your own pool.

To import candidates from your own ATS and CRM, click on the overflow or kebab menu at the top right corner and click Import candidates. In the modal that opens up, upload a CSV with the Name and Email ID of candidates to bring in your own candidates. If in doubt about the format, download the sample CSV shown in the modal and start uploading your candidates onto Engage.

As the next step, you need to reach out to these candidates and nudge them to register for the event. You can do that by Applying the filters (if there are any).

  1. Select the candidates using the checkbox.
  2. Click Email.
  3. Edit the Email and send the email to the candidates.

This will help you send a one-time nudge email to all the candidates you have imported to register for the event. 

Important: The email content needs to have the microsite link to allow these candidates to visit your microsite and register. See the image for a sample nudge email:

Publish the Event on the HackerRank Community

You can publish the event microsite link on the HackerRank community to get candidates for your event. This will be published under the compete page so that you can build candidates as you need.

Manage Candidates

Candidates in your funnel are displayed in the Candidates tab of Engage. 

In addition to importing, viewing the Event winners, and sending one-time emails, the Candidates tab can be used for managing the candidate data:

  • Data Management: View and search candidate data or team data and apply filters across various dimensions such as Gender, Country, and Experience level.

The Filter Candidates panel displays the filters to be applied. Select the appropriate filter and click Apply Filters.

  • The Candidates tab will have just the ‘Candidates’ sub-tab if it is an individual event, as seen below.

The Candidates tab will have both the Teams and Candidates sub-tabs if it is a team event, as seen below.

Related Articles:

  • HackerRank Engage
  • Create an Event
  • Set up the Promotional Emails or Campaigns
  • Set Up the Challenge
  • View Event Stats
  • End your Event on a High Note With the Leaderboard

articles.name: FAQs Related to Engage
articles.title: FAQs Related to Engage
articles.body:
HackerRank’s Professional Service team can help you in updating your Microsite based on your requirements. Note that HackerRank accepts up to two instances of change requests and not more.

You cannot reuse a Microsite and associate it with your new Event. HackerRank’s Professional Service team can help you.

The platform concurrency (concurrency across all our customers) will be capped based on the question type used as shown below:

  • Coding: 30k
  • Projects: 1k
  • Multiple Choice: 75k
    Note that the Event date has to be moved to a later date if it overshoots the platform’s concurrency for the day on which the Event is planned.
    If you require more attempts for the Event, you will have to purchase an additional attempts package from HackerRank.

You cannot reuse a Microsite and associate it with your new Event. HackerRank’s Professional Service team can help you.

Dedicated support refers to having a dedicated support person for your Event. Yes, you can request dedicated technical support for your Event, and we can make round-the-clock support available for your event starting end of April 23.

The product enables you to market your Event to potential candidates through the workflow functionality. Additionally, the following channels are provided by HackerRank:

  • HackerRank Ads: The Ads are targeted based on the experience level, country, gender, or the Intent (jobseeker or not) of the candidate. The Ads are published in two places on the Community: The landing page, Topic-specific pages of the Prepare tab.
  • Publishing the Microsite on the HackerRank Community. The Microsite is published on the Compete page of the HackerRank Community. This cannot be targeted to specific candidate cohorts.

Note: HackerRank will not commit to any registration or participation numbers as a result of this outreach activity.

The following marketing activities are not included:

  • Prize fulfillment
  • Email blast to the Community
  • Social Media Marketing (Facebook, LinkedIn, or any other social accounts of HackerRank)

However, the excluded marketing activities can be included on a case-by-case basis.

 

Yes, it is possible to run events that are open for multiple days, but HackerRank recommends you to shorten the event duration to avoid cases of cheating.

Additionally, if you want to run a multi-day event, it is advised to go with a bigger set of questions (either custom or own questions) while utilizing other proctoring options + other cheating deterrents such as Section & Question shuffling, randomization, and so on.

 

You can download the excel reports from the Challenge page of the Engage platform. The steps are:

  1. Click on the Challenge name.
  2. Click on the Candidates tab of the Challenge.
  3. Click on status=Completed and download the excel report.

If you want to view the candidate report on the UI, follow similar steps. Instead of downloading an excel, you can click on the candidate's name to view their report.

 

You can have hackathons that require a team to participate in an offline mode and submit the code as an individual.

The HackerRank Engage product should not be sold to prospects because it requires access to the HackerRank for Work platform.

You can refer to this email templates document to get ideas on how to think about your email sequences.

You can operationalize various types of Challenges using the Engage platform for a wide variety of candidate pools.

articles.name: Ashby - HackerRank Integration Configuration Guide
articles.title: Ashby - HackerRank Integration Configuration Guide
articles.body:
Overview

HackerRank's Tests integrate with Ashby to facilitate a seamless and efficient candidate screening process for recruiters. As part of their interview workflow, Ashby users can directly send HackerRank Test invites to candidates and obtain the Test report for further evaluation.

This article provides you with detailed configuration steps on HackerRank and Ashby.

  • Prerequisites
  • Configuring Ashby Integration with HackerRank
    • Generating an API Key from HackerRank
    • Adding the API Key in Ashby

Prerequisites

In HackerRank for Work In Ashby
  • You must own an Enterprise plan with a Recruiter license.
  • You must have an activated Recruiter-type user account with Company Admin permissions.
  • Log in with this user account.
  • Log in using the Ashby account, which has the same email address as the HackerRank for Work Company Admin user account. This is important for sending HackerRank Test invites from Ashby.

Example: If the email address in HackerRank for Work is jackpeters@hackerrank.com, the Ashby user account must also include the same email address.

  • You must have relevant administrative permissions to the Integrations page.

Configuring Ashby Integration with HackerRank

When configuring the Ashby integration with HackerRank for the first time, the administrator generates an API key. The administrator must keep a record of this API key for further use.

Generating an API Key from HackerRank

    1. Log in to HackerRank for Work with the Company Admin user account.  
    2. On the home page, click the drop-down next to the user icon in the top right corner.
    3. Click Settings.
    4. On the left pane, click Integrations. The Integrations page is displayed. Scroll down and click Configure on the Ashby option. You can also search the Integration from the Search bar.
    5. Click Generate API Token to generate the API token. A unique API Key is displayed.
    6. Copy this key. You will need to add this key to the Ashby account to establish the integration.

  2. Note: Ensure to store the API key safely. Once the popup is closed, you cannot retrieve the key again.

Adding the API Key in Ashby

  1. Log in to Ashby, and click Integrations.
  2. Search and click the HackerRank tile.
  3. The HackerRank pane opens on the right. Click Enable HackerRank.
  4. Add the Ashby API key.
  5. Test whether the API is correct by clicking the Test API key icon.
  6. Now add the HackerRank API key that you generated from the HackerRank for Work platform.
  7. Select the integration partner as HackerRank from the drop-down.
  8. Click Create API Key. The API key is created, and the integration is enabled.
  9. To check the integration, go to Ashby API > API Keys. The integration with HackerRank is displayed as Active.

Note: The email ID that you have used with your Ashby account should be the same as the email ID associated with your HackerRank account for the integration to work seamlessly.

Related Articles:

Ashby - HackerRank Integration User Guide

articles.name: Plagiarism Best Practices Guide
articles.title: Plagiarism Best Practices Guide
articles.body:
This guide has been developed to assist you and your organization in understanding how plagiarism is detected, tracked, and reported upon with the HackerRank for Work Platform. You’ll also find considerations, takeaways, and suggested steps to prepare a HackerRank assessment and follow up on candidate submissions.

How does HackerRank flag a candidate for plagiarism?

Our plagiarism flag is an indicator that there is a similarity between the code written by two or more candidates. The goal is to identify candidate submissions with the likelihood of plagiarism by comparing candidate codes and augmenting this with certain behavioral signals.

In simple terms, we flag candidates by looking at code similarity between candidates’ attempts starting at a 75% match. HackerRank then makes use of certain behavioral signals to improve the precision.

  • For context, a 75% match score is considered when the candidate has written at least 10 lines of code. If the candidate has written less than 10 lines of code, we have a higher threshold for a match score of 90% to flag candidates for plagiarism. This is to ensure that we don’t flag candidates for questions that require writing simple code snippets of 10 lines of code or less.

Pre-Assessment: Test Creation Best Practices

  1. Create sections within the test and add questions of all difficulty levels - Easy, Medium & Hard. For example, creating multiple sections varying in difficulty.
      • Including sections harder in nature, will reduce plagiarism. 
          • Section 1 - Easy
          • Section 2 - Medium
          • Section 3 - Hard
  2. Create a Question Pool within each section and randomize the questions within a section to vary the test from one test-taker to another.
  3. Clone and modify assessment questions. 
      • Many plagiarism cases occur because of questions being leaked, which leads to candidates copy-pasting the solutions available online.
      • Cloning and modifying questions by adding alternate test cases, changes to the problem statement, etc., helps in two ways.
          • Candidates who copy and paste the standard answer from the web cannot acquire a high since their code doesn’t pass the newly modified test cases.
          • Through modifications to the problem statement along with adding scenarios relevant to your organization, the question will not easily be found on the internet.
  4. Keep the login window short and the test duration closer to the recommended time to avoid question leakage. 
      • For context, some companies with large test expirations times for their assessments have encountered upwards of 50% of their candidates being flagged for plagiarism.
      • Recommendations for the test login window (test expiration time) 
          • (Varies from one organization to another)
          • 15-20 mins - for up to 10K candidates sitting for a test
          • 30 mins -  10K + candidates sitting for a test
  5. Tab and Copy Paste Proctoring and other Test Integrity Settings
      • Today, Copy Paste tracking is enabled by default for all of your customer tests. This will deter candidates from pasting code into their assessment attempts. 
          • Copy-Paste information (Copy-Paste Frequency) is available in the excel report as well as individual candidate reports ( Reviewer can view the lines of code copy-pasted by the candidate )
      • Tab Proctoring will deter candidates from moving out of the test window. Tab proctoring also tracks the number of out of window exits made by the candidate as well as time spent outside the window. Both these details are available in the candidate excel report. Copy-Paste information (Copy-Paste Frequency) is available in the excel report as well as the individual candidate reports ( Reviewer can view the lines of code copy-pasted by the candidate ).
          • For more information about downloading an excel report, check out the Downloading PDF and Excel Test Reports article.
      • Use sections while creating tests and add randomization by allowing the system to pick a set of different questions for each candidate. Since each candidate may get different questions, it is difficult for the candidates to split the test questions among themselves and share answers. Refer here - Section-based testing (Creating test sections and how to use them) 
      • Enable the “shuffle questions” option, which would add another layer of randomization to the ordering of questions as well so that candidates cannot rely on question numbers for getting the answers. Refer here - Shuffle Questions and Question Points

      • The Hide Question Title lets you disallow candidates from using a question title as a prompt on search engines to find answers to screening questions. While the actual question tiles are hidden from the candidates, they will be replaced with a generic title like Question 01, Question 02, etc. (Learn more in the ConfiguringTest Integrity Settings support article)

  6. Leaked Questions 
      • Before taking the test LIVE, ensure that none of the test questions are leaked. If any questions have been leaked, it is recommended to remove and replace the leaked question within any test before inviting a candidate.
          • For more information, check out the Leaked Question Indicator article.
  7. Test Instructions
      • Mention very clearly in the “ test instructions” (under test settings = > “candidates” section” that there is zero tolerance for plagiarism, and copying will result in disqualification.

Post-Assessment: Best Practices

  1. Shortlisting plagiarized candidates from the excel report.
      • Attempt plagiarism - YES/NO 
      • This Yes/No includes “ Inside the Test & Outside the Test” plagiarism results.
          • For more information on downloading Excel Test Reports, access our Downloading PDF and Excel Test Reports article.
  2. Plagiarism Percentage
      • By default, the system will flag a candidate as plagiarized when the match score is greater than 75% if at least 10 lines of code are written by the candidate. If there are <10 lines of code, we will flag candidates for plagiarism only if the match score is greater than 90%. This is to ensure that we don’t flag candidates for questions that require writing simple code snippets (of <10 lines).
      • We recommend a sliding scale based upon the difficulty level for the questions which are part of your assessment. (This is to keep the number of candidates being flagged as potential plagiarism within reason for easier questions)
          • Easy questions = 90%
          • Medium questions = (80-90%)
          • Hard Questions = 75%
  3. Copy-paste activity
      • Copy-Paste Frequency tracks the number of times a candidate tries to copy-paste the code. An increase in this frequency reveals the elevation of malpractice by the candidate.
      • HackerRank recommends leaving the alert message prompt to candidates off.
        • This is to prevent candidates from trying other avenues of cheating aside from copy-paste. For example: Typing the code instead of copy-pasting it.
  4. Tab change activity
      • Out of window duration (in seconds)
      • Number of window exits (count)
        • HackerRank has observed that for all plagiarized attempts, the median value for the out of duration window is 65 seconds and the median value for the number of window exits is 1.
        • In turn, any candidates with an out of window duration greater than 65 seconds and the number of window exits is more than a singular exit, could be considered a suspicious attempt.  

Note: If you’d like to analyze a specific question, you can also review the question column in an excel report to check if there was a particular question for which the majority of the candidates were flagged for plagiarism. For such questions, chances are high that there is a solution available on the internet, or it may be an easy question. It’s also possible that this particular easy question has only limited solutions. Keep in mind, that there are potentially additional reasons.

How do we go about shortlisting plagiarized candidates directly from the platform?

To effectively identify candidates who potentially have plagiarized and be able to differentiate them from those who honestly entered in code, a manual review is highly recommended.

Review by Hiring Manager:

  • Review the code playback option to view a candidate’s entry.
    • Code playback is available under the Detailed Tab within a Candidate Report generated post-assessment/test.
      • This feature helps in playing the recording of the candidate’s code submitted for a given HackerRank Assessment. We capture the code snippet written by the candidate whenever the candidate runs the code and display the playback in the report.
        • For more information on Code Playback click here.
  • Note the copy-paste indicator (Has a large amount of code been pasted?)
    • The copy-paste indicator can be found on the Detailed Tab of a candidate report.
      • Check out the How to Check for Plagiarism in HackerRank Tests article for more information.
  • Review the time taken by the candidate to attempt the particular question.
    • Available on the Summary and Timeline Tabs of a candidate report. 
      • Then, view insights for questions to view how long candidates are spending on the question on average.
        • For more information, check out the Viewing Question Insights article.

What other help can you get from HackerRank on this topic:

  • Upon customer request, in selected cases, we can loop in the data teams to perform a complete analysis of the customer tests to see where they stand compared to our global average.

articles.name: Professional Hire
articles.title: Professional Hire
articles.body:
Overview

Hiring professional talent is a much different process than entry-level and mid-level talent. These individuals have between 5-8 years of professional experience. Professional or Senior level talent is often a more passive candidate. In many cases, they are sourced through a referral internally. Additionally, many senior-level individuals are already employed and you will find that there are fewer candidates. 

The below visual shows a typical, senior-level hiring process flow. In the following sections, we will go over key differences in hiring this level of talent.

Phase 1: Plan

When planning to hire senior-level talent, the process will need to be more collaborative. It’s important that you get everyone on the same page about what the process will look like. 

Decide as a team:

  • What experience level are you looking for? Sr. Manager, Lead, Director, VP, etc. 
  • Do they need to have strong domain experience and knowledge?
  • What ideal personality traits would be a good culture fit for the team 
  • Will this be a panel-style interview?
  • What is the review process for making a decision?

Many times a senior-level candidate will never receive a test. This will need to be decided upfront and may vary from candidate to candidate and from role to role.

Phase 2: Screen

Whereas early-talent and mid-level candidates will be given a multiple-choice or real-world project, as mentioned above Senior-level talent will not. Typically, the best practice during the screening phase will simply be a phone discussion with the hiring manager.  Since they are most likely sourced or referred there may need to be less upfront validation. Experience speaks for itself. This is also a great opportunity for the hiring manager to SELL your company and team to the candidate.

Use this time with the candidate to talk about:

  • The candidate’s experience. 
    • What are some projects that they were excited to work on?
    • What made the project successful?
    • What kind of projects would they like to work on in the future?
  • Innovative projects that the company is working on.
    • How will this role impact that project?

This screening is a chance for you to get a feel for the candidate and their interest. If there is a mutual interest, now is a good time to let them know that they will be invited to a virtual onsite interview. Set the expectations with them of what they can expect for the in-person interview. 

Before the interview, get the interview panel together again to re-align on the in-person interview. 

Phase 3: Interview

The interview phase will typically include a few interviewers. The beginning of the interview is usually the best time to ask behavioral questions to identify if the candidate is a good culture fit for the company.  These questions should have been identified in the Plan phase of the hiring process. 

The next half of the interview is more technical in nature. For a Senior-level role, you will want to avoid multiple-choice questions. The goal here is to have them showcase their problem-solving skills and their ability to build or fix a real-world application. 

Have them showcase this by using a Whiteboard Interview question type, or have them work up an architectural Diagram within the interview. 

Watch this short video to see how HackerRank Interview functionality can help.

 

Phase 4: Rank

When it comes to making a final decision on a candidate, the process will rely mostly on the importance of feedback from the interviewers and the consensus from the entire hiring team. The information that was entered into the scorecards can be used to make a final hiring decision. 

Check out how to review this information within the HackerRank Developer Skills Platform.

articles.name: Benchmarking inside Candidate Packet
articles.title: Benchmarking inside Candidate Packet
articles.body:
Overview

Benchmarking is a feature inside the HackerRank for Work platform that compares candidate’s scores on specific skills against a cohort of candidates who have been assessed on the same set of skills. As of now, the available cohorts for benchmarking are -

  • Candidates within the same organization.
  • Candidates across the HackerRank for Work platform.

Importance of Benchmarking

For a hiring manager, it is crucial to make hiring decisions that can be backed by data and this is where benchmarking comes in handy. As a hiring manager, you will receive additional signals with the help of benchmarking which in turn will help you evaluate candidates objectively and help you answer the question “how good is this developer”?

Essentially, benchmarking focuses on the following three cases.

  • CodeScreen Benchmarking - Real-Time data on a candidate’s performance can serve as a better criterion compared to static cut-offs. Thus, benchmarking enables hiring managers to make better screening decisions.
  • Interview Benchmarking - It is also possible to benchmark a candidate's Interview performance against the average rating given by an interviewer. It also helps you ensure a consistent benchmark across your interview panel. 
  • Debrief Packet - The benchmarking feature provides additional information on a candidate’s performance including their scores in CodeScreen (assessment) and , benchmarked against a cohort of candidates who have been assessed on the same skill.

View benchmarking inside Candidate Packet

  • To view your candidate’s benchmarking data, open the Candidate Packet. Click here to know more about how to view candidate packets.
  • Expand the View Benchmarking section as shown in the below image.
  • Click on the edit icon beside Benchmarking Group and select the cohort against which you want to compare the candidate’s performance. Select the appropriate option from the Benchmarking Group dropdown.
  • Once you select the benchmarking group, you will be able to view data of the candidate against the benchmarked skills. Click on the expand icon to expand each skill and view benchmarking data against the same. 

    For example, In the below image, the selected candidate is benchmarked against a group of candidates assessed by the same company in the last 365 days. You can see the comparative data on the candidate’s performance, in both online assessments as well as live interviews, against specific skills when you click on those skills.

Candidate packet and benchmarking together is a better way to look at a candidate's performance and also look at all the touchpoints. This will also help in making faster hiring decisions which will reduce time to hire.

articles.name: How to assess AWS/Cloud/DevOps Skills of a candidate on HackerRank?
articles.title: How to assess AWS/Cloud/DevOps Skills of a candidate on HackerRank?
articles.body:
Overview

In this article, we unpack HackerRank enabled capabilities to assess AWS skills. Before we proceed, to learn how to create, and score DevOps questions, please see here. 

DevOps questions are those that help to assess the Linux and cloud skills of a candidate. When a candidate takes a test consisting of DevOps questions, we set up their own sandbox Linux virtual machine to log in remotely. You can ask them to perform whatever tasks you like: install a package, create a file with certain contents, or perform an action with a specific tool like Chef, Puppet, Ansible, Docker, grep, sed, awk, etc.

DevOps Questions in the HackerRank library

Question types that can be used to assess AWS/DevOps

Some of the most common ways to assess AWS Skills are as below:

  1. Multiple Choice Questions 
  2. Hands-on Tasks
  3. System Design Questions

Multiple Choice Questions

Multiple-choice questions [MCQs], in general, assess conceptual knowledge and understanding of a skill. They're beneficial in providing some indicators of the candidate’s AWS skill level, as you can see below.

Multiple Choice Questions on AWS and GCP skills

Hands-on Tasks

Real-world or Hands-on tasks and questions require candidates to dive deeper and actually demonstrate their skill proficiency. Using the hands-on questions in our library, candidates can be measured on practical demonstrations and multiple solution paths. Some examples of questions in our library are as below.

Docker Hands-on Questions

System Design

The highest and most accurate insight into a candidate's AWS/DevOps skill is available by using System Design Questions. Customers can leverage whiteboard solutions on CodePair as well as Diagram questions to sketch out AWS architecture diagrams. These questions provide insights into the candidate's thought process.

Click here to learn more on using AWS, GCP and Electrical Stencils for Diagram Questions.

Mock AWS Diagram

Note: Validated by our HackerRank's Skills Advisory Council, we also provide the HackerRank Skills Directory which clearly defines the AWS competencies that can be leveraged while assessing candidates. Please see the key competencies in the AWS Skills Directory here.

articles.name: Test Insights
articles.title: Test Insights
articles.body:
Overview

The HackerRank Insights powered by Highcharts offers helpful analytics to assess candidate performance on your tests. The interactive graphs allow you to analyze trends in scores over time, question difficulty, and overall test completion.

Specifically, you can view score distribution graphs to see how your candidates are performing on a bell curve. The question-level analysis shows time taken per question compared to question accuracy. This shows which questions may need refining based on completion rates. Finally, the candidate performance graph demonstrates each individuals' scoring and pacing compared to the average.

These visual representations give actionable insights into a test's efficiency. You can use the trends to refine questions, pass top performers to the next hiring stage, or determine how well the test screens candidates' abilities. Optimizing a skills test leads to better candidate matches and a smoother hiring process. The user-friendly analytics make it easy to improve your assessments over time based on real data.

Note: HackerRank has made background changes to the existing insights to optimize performance and customizability. You may notice minute changes to the user interface and functionality, and some have observed faster loading times. There are no changes in the underlying data that the platform provides in insights.

This article provides guidance on how to adapt to the latest updates, ensuring that you can still access our insights.

Feel free to contact our support team at support@hackerrank.com with any questions during this transition.

Prerequisites

  • You must have created a Test and invited candidates.
  • You must have a considerable number of candidates who have attempted and submitted the Test.

Viewing Test Insights

  1. Navigate to Tests. Select the required Test.
  2. Click Insights to view the Test insights page.

Exploring Test Insights 

The insights dashboard presents test data as interactive graphs. Hovering over these graphs allows you to view details representing each data segment.

Basic Functionality

  • You can reload the insights anytime you want by clicking on the reload icon.
  • You can click on the hamburger menu icon attached to each section to perform multiple actions such as view the widget in full screen, download a CSV, JPG, PNG or PDF along with an option to clear cache and refresh respective widget.

The various sections on Insights Dashboard are explained below.

Test Details

The Test Details section displays details like test name, test ID, test creation, last updated dates, test owner name and email, and allotted duration. This data provides insights about the test's development history and structure for your reference. Access to these details allows for a quick grasp of essential logistics.

Test Activities

Test Activities section provides a brief summary of Test progression and candidate scores

Candidate Status

This pie chart represents the distribution of candidates passed, failed and yet to be evaluated. You can hover over this pie chart to view the details attached to each part of the graph. Place your cursor over a specific status to see the count of candidates. Hover your mouse over a particular status to view the number of candidates.

You can hover over this pie chart to view the details attached to each part of the graph. This chart helps you to understand the overall performance of candidates.

On the right side you can find following widgets:

  • Total Invited: Indicates the total number of candidates who are invited to the test.
  • Total Attempted: The total number of candidates who have submitted the test. 
  • Attempt Rate: Displays a percentile value of the candidates who have attempted the test against total invited candidates

.

Example: If you look at 134 Total Invited data displayed on top right widget, it indicates you have sent email invites to 134 individual candidates. Considering 118 candidates have attempted the Test (as displayed on middle right widget), the percentage attempted value is indicated as 88.1% (as displayed on bottom right widget).

Test Level Insights

Test Level Insights provide the following Test analyses:

A. Distribution of Candidates Scores 

This graph represents different range of scores achieved by candidates who have submitted the Test. Hover your mouse over a particular range indicated in the graph, and the tooltip displays the number of candidates who have achieved a score in this range. 

This score distribution graph helps you estimate the number or percentage of candidates likely to succeed in the Test and be considered for hiring.

B. Median Score 

50% of the candidates who attempted this test scored less than or equal to this score.

Indicates the median value from different candidates’ test scores. This value serves as a benchmark score to identify candidates who qualify and those who don’t.

C. Median Attempt Time (Minutes)

50% of the candidates who attempted this test took less than or equal to this time.

Indicates the median value from different candidates’ test completion times. This median value serves as a benchmark correlation to separate the faster and slower test takers.

Example: If the value is 10m 45s, it implies that 50% of your candidates completed this Test in less than or equal to the median time.

D. Median Time to Full Score (Minutes)

50% of the candidates who scored 100% on this test took less than or equal to this amount of time.

Indicates the median value from different test completion times considering only those Tests in which candidates have achieved a full score. This median value serves as a benchmark correlation to separate test takers who achieved a full score in the shortest possible time.

Example: If the value is 15m 30s, it implies that 50% of your candidates completed this Test with a full score in less than or equal to the median time.

E. Test Feedback

Average test feedback star rating out of 5.

Question Level Insights

For every Question in the Test, these graphs represent the median and average value of the scores achieved. You can use this graph to understand which test questions gained a higher or lower score.

A. Median Score per Question:  The median score for each test question.

B. Average Score per Question: The average score for each test question.

C. Median Time per Question: The median time to solve each question.

D. Average Time per Question: The average time to solve each question.

Performance Funnel - All Candidates

Test Invited: Total number of candidates invited to the test, including those who may or may not have attempted the test.

Test Link Clicked: Total number of candidates who clicked the link to take the test.

Test Attempted: A total number of candidates who submitted the test. 

Test Attempted At Least One Question: Total number of candidates who attempted at least one question.

Test Attempt Insights 

 

# of Attempts Over Time: These graphs represent the number of attempts per attempt start date.

% Attempt Duration Distribution: These graphs represent the number of attempts plotted against the attempt duration percentage bucket.

articles.name: Creating a Test Based on a Specific Role
articles.title: Creating a Test Based on a Specific Role
articles.body:
Overview

HackerRank for Work generates Tests based on the selected role. For roles created by HackerRank, recruiters can easily generate Tests by including skill-mapped questions from the HackerRank Library.

You can refer to this article to learn more about Roles and Skills.

You can follow the below steps to learn more about how you can create a role-specific test from your HackerRank for Work account.

Create a Test from the Test Dashboard

Follow the below steps to create a Test on a specific role.

  • On the Test tab, click on the Create Test button.
  • The test creation wizard that opens allows you to select a particular role you want to generate the test.
  • You can either type the role you are looking for in the search bar or scroll down and select it from the list. 

  • Once you select the required role, the skills associated with that role get displayed below it. Click on the Create Test button to create a test based on the selected role.

  • On clicking Create Test, a new test is generated, and the skill sections lists the mapped skills and questions under them.  These Questions are relevant to the skills mapped to the selected role.
  • On the test page, you can access the details such as selected role, core skills mapped to that role and other relevant skills. You can click on the + icon beside the relevant skills to add them to your assessment.  

Adding a New Skill Section

  • Click on Add New+ and select from the available options: 
  • Add Skill Based Questions: Add questions curated by HackerRank  mapped to each skill.
  • Add Manually: Add questions from HackerRank or My Company library. 

  • If you select Add Skill Based Questions you will be asked to choose the skills.
  • There are two types of skill bundles: 
    • Basic Skill Bundles:
      • These are standard skill bundles. The questions in these bundles are mapped to specific skills. These bundles are not protected from leakage. In case of a question leak you have to manually change that question within the test. 
    • Leak Protected Skill Bundles: You can identify one with 
      • The questions in these skill bundles are safeguarded against leakage 
      • HackerRank manages these skill bundles exclusively. If any questions from these bundles are leaked, HackerRank replaces the compromised questions with new ones.
      • Leak protected skill bundles are highlighted with the safeguard icon as shown below. 

  • The skills are differentiated at three levels: 
    • Basic: Consists of questions with easy difficulty. 
    • Intermediate: Consists of questions with medium difficulty.
    • Advanced: Consists of questions with Hard difficulty. 
  • Next, you can choose the Question Type, such as Coding, MCQ, or Project.

 

  • After selecting the desired Skill and Question type, click the add to the test. You can view that your selected skill is now present in your test as a new section. 

Adding Questions Manually

  • Select the Add Manually option after clicking on Add New+.

  • Select Add From Library or Create Question option.  

  • When you select Add From Library you will be taken to the HackerRank library where you can select the desired question using the available filtering options. Click on the plus icon to add the question.  Selected questions will appear on the left pane of the screen. 

 

  • Once done you can click on Go Back to Test to proceed with the test. Selected questions are added as a section.   

Skill Section Settings

  • Hover over the skill section and click on the settings icon 
  • Within the skill section settings you can change its name, select the number of questions for it and change the time limit to answer that section.  
  • From the Advanced Settings you can: 
    • Control if you want the candidates to see the sections. When disabled candidates will only see the questions within a test.  
    • Enable or disable the sections to be shuffled for the candidates. 
    • Allow or disallow the candidates to revisit previous sections once answered.  
    • Allow the candidates to use the duration left in previous sections for the upcoming sections.  

Note: You must add duration to each section to enable the above three settings.   

 

Removing a Section

Hover your cursor over the skill you want to remove and click the delete icon. This will remove that skill section you chose.

Once done you can Publish the test and start inviting the candidates.

Create a Test from the Roles Management

You can also create a Test specific to a Role from the Roles Dashboard. 

  • Log in to your HackerRank for Work account and click on the Roles Management option from the top-right menu.

  • The Roles Management page lists all the roles available on the HackerRank for Work platform.

  • You can use the search option to search for the specific role for which you want to create the test. The skills that are mapped to the specific Role are displayed below the Role.
  • Click on the horizontal ellipsis beside the role and click on the Create Test option. 
  • Remember that you can create a test only from published roles.

  • The test creation window pops up with the specific Role automatically selected from the dropdown on clicking the Create Test button. 

  • Follow the same workflow as mentioned above to create a test based on the selected role.
